title: Markdown rendering and preview for product/collection descriptions
description:
Imported from GitHub #473

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, product and collection descriptions are displayed as plain text. Even if merchants write markdown, it's not rendered, making descriptions less readable and professional.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
1. **Markdown rendering** - Render markdown syntax in description fields when displaying products/collections
2. **Preview tab** - Add a "Write" / "Preview" toggle in the description editor (like GitHub) so merchants can see how their markdown will look before publishing

Supported syntax should include:
- Headings, bold, italic, strikethrough
- Bullet and numbered lists
- Links
- Code blocks
- Blockquotes

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
- Rich text editor (WYSIWYG) - More complex and harder to maintain consistency across Nostr clients
- Plain text only - Limited formatting capabilities

**Additional context**
Related to #465 which notes that descriptions "can be markdown" - this issue specifically addresses rendering that markdown and providing a preview experience.

The markdown source would be stored in the Nostr event content, remaining compatible with other clients.

title: Deleted product still appears in list after deletion
description: Imported from GitHub #413 ## Description After deleting a product, a success popup/toast confirms the deletion, but the product remains visible in the product list until a manual refresh. ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Go to Dashboard > Products 2. Delete a product 3. Observe success message appears 4. Product is still visible in the list ## Expected Behavior The product should be immediately removed from the list after successful deletion, without requiring a page refresh. ## Current Behavior - Success message shows "Product deleted" (or similar) - Product remains in the list - Only disappears after manual page refresh ## Possible Cause The product list query is not being invalidated/refetched after the delete mutation completes. ## Suggested Fix After successful deletion, invalidate the products query to trigger a refetch: ```typescript queryClient.invalidateQueries({ queryKey: productKeys.all }) ``` ## Screenshots ## Related Issues - #412 - Confirmation dialog for delete is not branded ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

title: PR Preview Deployments for Easy Review
description:
Imported from GitHub #483

## Summary

Implement automated PR preview deployments so reviewers can test PRs without compiling locally. Each PR gets its own preview URL like `pr-123.staging.plebeian.market`.

cc @EdiWeeks @ChiefmonkeyArt @woikos 

## Problem

Currently, reviewing PRs requires:
1. Checking out the branch locally
2. Installing dependencies
3. Running the dev server
4. Testing manually

This creates friction for:
- **Product owners** reviewing UX changes
- **UI testers** validating visual updates
- **Contributors** on "help wanted" issues who need feedback before investing more time

## Proposed Solution

**Something like this anyway**

### Architecture
- **Wildcard DNS**: `*.staging.plebeian.market ‚Üí 176.58.119.108` (one-time setup)
- **Docker containers**: Each PR runs in isolated container on unique port
- **nginx**: Routes subdomains to containers dynamically
- **GitHub Actions**: Manual trigger to deploy, auto-cleanup on merge

### URL Format
```
pr-{number}.staging.plebeian.market
```
Example: `pr-462.staging.plebeian.market`

### Workflow
1. Reviewer clicks "Run workflow" on the deploy-preview action
2. Enters PR number
3. GitHub Action builds and deploys to a slot
4. Bot comments on PR with preview URL
5. On PR merge/close, slot is automatically cleaned up

### Slot Management
- **Manually triggered** to control resource usage
- **Maximum 5 concurrent slots** (configurable)
- Port assignment: PR number + 3000 (e.g., PR #123 ‚Üí port 3123)

## Benefits

- **Faster reviews**: Click a link instead of local setup
- **Better for "help wanted" issues**: External contributors get quick UX feedback
- **Product owner friendly**: Non-technical reviewers can test directly
- **Consistent environment**: Same as staging, no "works on my machine" issues

## One-time Setup Required

1. Add wildcard DNS at DreamHost: `*.staging.plebeian.market`
2. Install Docker on Linode (if not present)
3. Configure nginx for dynamic subdomain routing
4. Create GitHub workflow files

## Implementation Tasks

- [ ] Add wildcard DNS record
- [ ] Set up Docker on Linode server
- [ ] Create nginx wildcard config template
- [ ] Create `deploy-preview.yml` workflow
- [ ] Create `cleanup-preview.yml` workflow (on PR close)
- [ ] Add PR comment bot for preview URLs
- [ ] Document usage in CONTRIBUTING.md

title: Make relays visible to users and clarify relay selection
description:
Imported from GitHub #410

## Description

Users should be able to see which relays they are connected to and understand how relay selection works.

## Questions to Address

- Does the app use the user's NIP-05 relays?
- What relays is the user currently connected to?
- How are relays selected/configured?

## Suggested Solution

Add UI element (possibly in settings or a status indicator) that shows:
- Currently connected relays
- Source of relay configuration (app default, NIP-05, user-configured, etc.)
- Connection status for each relay

## Why This Matters

In a decentralized system, users should understand where their data is being published and read from. This transparency builds trust and helps with troubleshooting.

title: Allow users to define and publish their Kind 10002 relay list
description:
Imported from GitHub #418

## Summary

> Written by Claude Code

Allow users to configure their preferred relays (kind 10002 / NIP-65) within the market app, so products are published to their chosen relays rather than only the hardcoded defaults.

## Current Behavior

- Products are published to hardcoded relays in `constants.ts` (relay.damus.io, nos.lol, relay.nostr.band, relay.nostr.net, relay.minibits.cash)
- NDK's outbox model is enabled, but only works if the user has already published a kind 10002 event from another client
- Users have no way to configure their relay preferences within the market app

## Suggested Behavior

1. **Read existing kind 10002** - On login, fetch the user's existing relay list (if any)
2. **Relay management UI** - Allow users to add/remove relays in dashboard settings
3. **Publish kind 10002** - Save changes by publishing an updated kind 10002 event
4. **Use for publishing** - Products, updates, and deletions should be sent to user's configured relays

## Technical Notes

- Kind 10002 is a replaceable event (NIP-65)
- Tags use format: `["r", "wss://relay.example.com", "write"]` or `["r", "wss://relay.example.com"]` for both read/write
- See: https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/65.md

## Related

- #414 - Relay status display (shows which relays have products)

title: Handle unexpected Kind-16 messages containing product JSON
description:
Imported from GitHub #437

## Problem

Merchants are receiving Kind-16 messages that display as:

> **Unsupported Kind 16 (type: unknown)**
> `{"id":"...","kind":30402,"tags":[["title","Lightning Piggy"]...]}`

### Context

Received this message to **RobotechyShop** from **Gemma** (YoJimble). Will follow up with her to understand how she shared it - presumably via Plebeian Market.

### What We Know

- The Kind-16 message contains a full **Kind-30402 product event** as JSON in the content field
- It lacks our expected `type` tag ("1", "2", "3", or "4") for order protocol messages
- The `["type", "simple", "physical"]` present is a **product attribute tag**, not our message type

### What We Don't Know

- **Why is this being sent as Kind-16?** Our protocol uses Kind-16 for order processing, but this doesn't match that format
- **What user action triggered it?** Possibly "contact seller", sharing a product, or attempting checkout
- **Is this legacy Plebeian Market behavior?**

### Example Event Content

```json
{
  "id": "00facb931f4c13cc24eb79c7bf982ff550bdb40ad160fe10154dba9ab53f802a",
  "pubkey": "211f325b5396968ac0c79b7c0a030d768206d32ac61f93f143de112b859bd46f",
  "kind": 30402,
  "tags": [
    ["d", "product_1766247644889_96qrc"],
    ["title", "Lightning Piggy"],
    ["price", "60", "GBP"],
    ...
  ]
}
```

### Next Steps

1. Ask Gemma what action she took to trigger this message
2. Investigate if this is legacy Plebeian Market protocol
3. If legitimate use case, add graceful handling to display embedded products nicely

### Affected Files

- `src/components/messages/ChatMessageBubble.tsx`

title: Allow filtering products by location/region
description:
Imported from GitHub #436

## Feature Request

Allow users to filter products by location/region, such as finding "Meat in the UK" or "Wine from France".

## Problem

Currently there's no way to filter products by geographical location. Users who want to:
- Buy local products
- Find region-specific items (wine from specific regions, local specialties)
- Avoid international shipping costs
- Support local merchants

...have no way to narrow their search geographically.

## Proposed Solution

Add location-based filtering capabilities:

1. **Seller location filtering**
   - Filter products by seller's location/country
   - Could use location from shop profile (see #435)

2. **Product origin filtering**
   - Some products have origin (e.g., "French Wine", "Italian Cheese")
   - Could be a product tag

3. **Shipping region filtering**
   - Filter by where products ship to
   - Based on shipping options configured by seller

## UI Considerations

- Add location filter dropdown/search to product listing page
- Could integrate with search (e.g., "wine france" could trigger location filter)
- Map view for browsing products by location

## Related Issues

- #435 (Shop profile customization - shops may have different locations from personal nPub)

title: Allow shops to have separate profile details from nPub (NIP-15 Stalls concept)
description:
Imported from GitHub #435

## Feature Request

A shop/store may want to have different details (banner, info, location, etc.) from its parent nPub (personal profile). 

## Problem

Currently, the shop profile is tied directly to the user's Nostr profile (kind 0). This means:
- Shop name = Personal name
- Shop banner = Personal banner
- Shop location = Personal location
- Shop description = Personal about section

## Proposed Solution

Allow merchants to configure a separate "shop profile" that overrides or supplements their personal nPub profile for marketplace purposes. This could include:
- Shop name / Display name
- Shop banner image
- Shop description / About
- Shop location
- Shop avatar/logo
- Business contact information

## Benefits

This aligns with NIP-15 (Nostr Marketplace) design philosophy where a merchant identity can be distinct from a personal identity. Benefits include:
- Professional branding separate from personal profile
- Privacy - merchants may not want to share personal info
- Multiple storefronts from one nPub
- Better organization for users who have both personal and business presence on Nostr

## Implementation Considerations

- Could use a marketplace-specific kind event for shop profiles
- Or use tags on the user's profile to indicate marketplace-specific overrides
- Should be backwards compatible - fallback to nPub profile if no shop profile exists
